work.p: The second line in this manuscript is distantly similar to language that appears in the first poem in the 1855 edition of Leaves of Grass, which was later titled "Song of Myself": "And there is no trade or employment but the young man following it may become a hero" (1855, p. 54).

titleStmt.title: Why should I subscribe money
a machine readable transcription
titleStmt.author: Walt Whitman
titleStmt.sponsor: Center for Digital Research in the Humanities, University of Nebraska-Lincoln

availability.p: The text of the original item is in the public domain. The text encoding and editorial notes were created and/or prepared by the Walt Whitman Archive and are licensed under a Creative Commons Attribution 4.0 International License (CC BY 4.0). Any reuse of the material should credit the Walt Whitman Archive. Permission to reproduce the graphic images of the original item has been granted by the owners of the original for this publication only.

notesStmt.note: Whitman may have drafted this manuscript between 1850 and 1855, as he was composing the first (1855) edition of Leaves of Grass. Language in the manuscript bears some similarity to language in the first poem in that edition, eventually titled "Song of Myself."

bibl.author: Walt Whitman

bibl.note: Transcribed from digital images of the original.
A poetry draft on the back of this manuscript may relate to "Song of Myself."

revisionDesc.change: created separate id for manuscript; was previously encoded with verso
checked and corrected file, added corresps

lg.l:
Why should I subscribe money to build a some general's hero's statue ? for
the greatest
That butcher boy with is just as great a hero
He does not know what fear is
